results.title: La Collectionneuse = the Collector Girl
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard, Barbet Schroeder and Eric Rohmer
results.brief_description:
Feeling vaguely abandoned as his girlfriend has gone to London, Adrian, a dilettante philosopher, goes to stay at a friend’s villa on the outskirts of St. Tropez. Daniel, an avant-garde artist, and Haydee, a sweetly amoral nymphette who sleeps with a different boy every night, are there also. As the collector of the title, she causes disarray in the two men who decide it is their duty to resist her advances - an intellectual rather than physical moral superiority. It is Adrian, frustrated and chastened, who finally fulfills the moral outline of the series, by hopefully planning a reconciliation with his girlfriend. ‘La Collectionneuse’ was the first feature Rohmer made in 35mm and colour. This is the fourth installement of Rohmer’s ‘Six Moral Tales’.

Credits: Producers, Georges de Beauregard, Barbet Schroeder ; director, Eric Rohmer ; writer, Eric Rohmer ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Les Blossom Toes, Giorgio Gomeslky.
Cast: Patrick Bauchau, Haydee Politoff, Daniel Pommereulle, Seymour Hertzberg.

results.title: La Cite de L'indicible Peur
results.brief_description:
Mickey, a dangerous mobster, has been arrested ‘by chance’ by Triquet, a rather insignificant police officer. Mickey is condemned to death but manages to escape. Triquet is ordered to trace him all the way to the village of Barges in Auvergne (central France).

Credits: Producer, Paul Laffargue ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Jean-Pierre Mocky, Gerard Klein ; photography, Eugen Schuftan ; music, Gerard Calvi ; editor, Marguerite Renoir.
Cast: Bourvil, Jean-Louis Barrault, Francis Blanche, Veronique Nordey, Jacques Dufilho, Rene-Louis Lafforgue, Jean Poiret, Raymond Rouleau.

results.title: La Chinoise = the Chinese Girl
results.brief_description:
Veronique is a philosophy student. She is also the leader of a small group of friends who are interested in Marxist ideas. She lives in an apartment lined with shelves full of little red books. The group is made up of Guillaume, actor, Henri, student, Kirilov, a painter and Yvonne, prostitute. They are so taken by the external trappings of their cause — the posters, the Little Red Books, the by-rote chantings — that they seem not to grasp the true meaning of their political persuasion. Nor do they give any thought to the long-range ramifications of their terrorist activities. One day, Veronique proposes to assassinate a famous person. ‘La Chinoise’ is a montage film. Godard filmed each sequence as an autonomous piece, in no particular order. There was no preset idea about the chronology nor the ending. Some exterior scenes were shot on the Nanterre University Campus which was to become the starting point of the May 68 student movement.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard.
Cast: Anne Wiazemsky, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Juliet Berto, Michel Semeniako, Lex de Brujn, Omar Diop, Francis Jeanson.

results.title: La Chienne = the Bitch
results.brief_description:
An unhappily married clerk falls for a prostitute, steals from his employer to satisfy her demands, and kills her out of jealousy of her pimp. ‘La chienne’ exemplifies Renoir’s mise-en-scene. An exceptional sense of space is created by complex, though unobtrusive, staging in depth, long takes (even by French standards), and the use of sound counterpoints. The overall effect is a dynamic linking of characters to their environment. Casual acting, sometimes by non-professionals, is also a hallmark. Yet Renoir’s realism goes hand in hand with the theatrical, most of his films alluding to, or staging, spectacles”. Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The Companion to French Cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996. ‘La chienne’ was the film in which Renoir became fully aware of the social dimensions of speech. The range of vocal styles in the film makes its soundtrack not merely interesting in texture (as aural montage), but implicitely redolent of class conflict. ‘La chienne’ also features the first of a striking series of murders and other violent deaths that recurr obsessively in the director’s works of the 1930s. Many critics tend to depict Renoir as a genial, gentle humanist. But in most of his films of the 1930s people are, quite simply, out to kill one another sooner or later. In mid-decade, if we are to judge by his films, Renoir came to believe that some good could emerge from the violence that seems to have obsessed him. After the demise of the Popular Front, however, he returned to the view of life implicit in ‘La chienne’: murder expresses a truth that most people do not wish to accept, that aggression and conflict are implicit in human relations - and most strongly between members of different classes. But the killing does not change anything; life goes on around it, in a kind of awful harmony with it”. Reference: Alan Williams. Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking. Harvard University Press, 1992. Re-made as ‘Scarlett Street’, directed by Fritz Lang (1945) [Held in our collection].

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger, Roger Richebe ; director, Jean Renoir ; writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Theodore Sparkuhl ; music, Toselli ; editors, Jean Renoir, Marguerite Houlle-Renoir, Denise Batcheff ; assistant director, Yves Allegret,
Cast: Michel Simon, Janie Marese, Magdeleine Berubet, Georges Flamant, Romain Bouquet, Colette Borelli, Max Dalban, Jane Pierson.

results.title: La Chartreuse de Parme = the Charterhouse of Parma
results.brief_description:
Fabrice returns to Parma to live with his aunt, Duchess Sanseverina. He is unaware of her feelings for him and looks for amourous adventures all over town. A jealous man challenges him to a duel and Fabrice kills him. After his arrest and trial, Fabrice is condemned to 12 years imprisonment and taken to the Farnese tower. There, he seduces Clelia, the daughter of the prison governor.

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Christian-Jaque ; writers, Christian-Jaque, Pierre Very, Pierre Jary ; photography, Nicolas Hayer, Romolo Garrone ; music, Renzo Rosselini.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Renee Faure, Maria Casares, Lucien Coedel, Albert Remy, Louis Salou.

results.title: La Chambre
results.brief_description:
Pierre is happily married to Eve and lives a comfortable existence. One day, as he is scheduled for a business trip, Eve finds him prostrate in the bathroom. Little by little, Pierre seems to lose contact with reality, refusing to leave his room and conducting dialogues with an other woman.

Credits: Director, Michel Mitrani ; writers, Gerard Jarlot, Michel Mitrani ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet.
Cast: Michel Auclair, Mireille Perey, Jean-Roger Caussimon, Marc Heyrand, Andree Tainsy.

results.title: La Chaise Vide = the Empty Chair
results.brief_description:
Anne is raising her child alone and works in a photo library. She is waiting for her reporter lover to return from the war in Africa and refuses any offer to start a new life with Maxime, a musician.

Credits: Director, Pierre Jallaud ; writers, Pierre Jallaud, Maxime Le Forestier ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Maxime Le Forestier.
Cast: Martine Chevalier, Daniel Quenaud, Maxime Le Forestier, Cyril Stockman, Evane Hanska.

results.title: La Ceremonie
results.creator_credit: MK2 Productions, Canal+, Olga-Film, France 3 Cinema, Marin Karmitz and Claude Chabrol
results.brief_description: Chabrol has called this sinister psycho-drama revolving around issues of class conflict and familial discontent “the last Marxist film”. Based on the novel ‘A Judgement in Stone’ by Ruth Rendell the film centres on a wealthy liberal couple living in rural Brittany who employ Sophie, a taciturn young woman, as a live-in maid. Initially satisfied with her work they become disapproving when she forms a close bond with the irreverent local postmistress. Their strange friendship and increasingly odd antics make the family increasingly suspicious of Sophie and when they finally reject her, the two friends exact a chilling revenge. This film is widely considered to mark Chabrol’s return to form as a director of thrillers. Cast includes Isabelle Huppert, Sandrine Bonnaire, Jacqeline Bisset and Jean-Pierre Cassel.
